an9.71:4.1: “Mendicants, there are these five kinds emotional barrenness.
an9.71:4.3: Firstly, a mendicant has doubts about the Teacher. They’re uncertain, undecided, and lacking confidence.
an9.71:4.4: This being so, their mind doesn’t incline toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and endeavor.
an9.71:4.5: This is the first kind of emotional barrenness.
an9.71:5.1: Furthermore, a mendicant has doubts about the teaching …
an9.71:5.4: A mendicant is angry and upset with their spiritual companions, resentful and closed off.
an9.71:5.5: This being so, their mind doesn’t incline toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and endeavor.
an9.71:5.6: This is the fifth kind of emotional barrenness.
an9.71:6.1: To give up these five kinds of emotional barrenness you should develop the four kinds of mindfulness meditation. …”
